Award.AwardTitle: Identification of mechanisms for motor pattern selection during multimodal sensory integration.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Central pattern generators are networks or individual nerve cells in animals and humans that govern vital functions of the body, including breathing, swallowing and chewing. Their activity is robust, but switches between different states when body or environmental conditions change. Such switches can be achieved by control neurons that release neuromodulators - chemical substances that dramatically alter network behavior. Control neurons collect information from all senses, but their conjoint activity and how their activity leads to appropriate behavioral responses is unknown. This proposal asks how sensory information is encoded by these nerve cells and how appropriate behavioral responses are selected. The hypothesis that appropriate behavioral responses are encoded in the population activity of control neurons will be tested in the stomatogastric nervous system of crabs, a powerful model system with unique access to neurons.

The researchers will use a combination of high-end optical imaging and intracellular electrophysiology to measure and manipulate most control neurons while they select the appropriate behaviors during sensory stimulation. Expected results are that the encoding of sensory stimuli differs between different sensory inputs and that these differences are necessary and sufficient to cause switches in behavior. The proposed research provides comprehensive training for students at different stages of their careers (undergraduate, graduate and postdoc) and teaches a variety of established and recently developed scientific techniques. It will open new lines of research in systems where the investigation of control networks is not feasible due to the sheer number of neurons. Revealing the mechanisms of behavioral selection is crucial to our understanding of nervous system function and, ultimately, a prerequisite for the treatment of sensory disorders such as autism and learning disabilities. This project will also instruct engineers about ways of decision making without dedicated pathways and may thus lead to new and efficient neural networks in machines and robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most fascinating abilities of the brain is to respond adequately to sensory stimuli it receives from the environment. But how does the nervous system decide what action to take, and how to respond to particular sensations? How do various different sensory pathways interact in the nervous system to allow these decisions? This project has addressed these question by studying rhythmic motor neurons in the experimentally advantageous crustacean stomatogastric nervous system. Rhythmic motor systems govern large parts of our behavior and many vital functions such as walking, breathing or chewing. The underlying neural circuits are functionally flexible to accommodate a constantly changing sensory environment. They are thus ideal to study sensory influences. They are also universal in that the general principles of their functioning are the same in all animals and humans.

Intellectual merit: We found that sensory information from different sensory modalities is encoded in a combinatorial code of the activated neurons. Like in a very large combination lock with hundreds of digits, the population activity differs in different sensory conditions, and this code determines the behavioral actions. As a first step, we characterized the anatomy of the neuronal network that receives the sensory information. Using fluorescence stainings, we created a 3-dimensional map of all neurons in this network. In a second step we measured the population activities in this network, but with single neuron resolution. In this way, we were able to track each neuron's changes in activity in different sensory conditions. We either stimulated a chemosensory pathway (olfaction), a mechanosensory one, or both together. We found that there are no separate pathways for these conditions in the nervous system. Rather, and unlike most engineering solutions for processing sensory information in machines, the majority of the neurons (>80%) processed all sensory stimuli and a new combination of excitation and inhibition was present in each condition. Most excitingly, even when olfaction and mechanosensation were combined, a new combination appeared. This may represent a new mechanism by which neuronal networks identify combined inputs. Interestingly, we also found that sensory pathways interact even before they reach the central nervous system: the olfactory pathway altered the response of another sensory pathway by directly altering signal integration in sensory neurons. This unexpected finding allows one sense to prime another to make it more responsive to future sensations.

Broader impacts: Funds from this grant have trained undergraduate, graduate students and postdocs and allowed them to attend national and international meetings, including presentations in Europe, South America, and Australia. Several students have received awards for best poster and oral presentations at these meetings. PhD students funded by this grant have received the 2016 Young Investigator Award of the International Society for Neuroethology, the Trainee Professional Development Award from the Society for Neuroscience 2018, and the Outstanding College Student Award of McLean County 2018. Locally, students funded by this grant have received best PhD dissertation and best PhD student teaching awards at our university.

The principle investigator has presented the research funded by this grant at several national and international invited seminars, including a keynote at the 111th Annual Meeting of the German Zoological Society. The lab's research was also prominently featured by BBC Canada and the Science Friday Radio Show. At Illinois State University, the lab has hosted several outreach activities, including visits by local high school students and by a group of undergraduate students from China. The lab also visited the University's child care center and introduced groups of 3 - 6 year olds to basic research and brain functions. Graduate students have also reached out to the local community at the Alpha Phi Omega Children's Carnival in Normal, IL, and the McLean County STEM Gala, and they serve as judges for a local high school research symposium.

The principle investigator is an advisor for the Biological Sciences Student Association, a club for undergraduate students in Biology. The club meets biweekly and invites scientists with diverse backgrounds and individuals from professional organizations as well as educators from the local community.

NSF funding has allowed the principle investigator to recruit several new undergraduate and graduate students, including minority students who were funded by this grant during their time as undergraduate and graduate students. Professionally, the lab regularly organizes the Neuroethology and Invertebrate Neuroscience social at the Society for Neuroscience meeting with more than 100 participants, and the principle investigator has given a speech to the public at the local March for Science.

The data produced by this project are open access and freely available, and we keep our website updated with weekly news and results from our NSF project. We also have a Youtube channel where we disseminate our research questions and approaches to the scientific community. Several of these videos are aimed at undergraduate students and the general public.
